'''Chinese encyclopedias''' (Chinese: Zhōngwén chūbǎn) are compendia dealing with different subject areas such as classics or contemporary topics. Encyclopedias are important reference resources for students because they offer explanations of core concepts.

The first known full-length Chinese encyclopedia, Zizhi Tongjian was a historical compendium compiled by the clerks of Emperor Yingzong of Song from 1065–1084. Because of its length, it has been cited numerous times through later editions and compendia. The first Chinese encyclopedia to have a systematic and hierarchically categorized format was the Yongle Encyclopedia, compiled by the Minister of Rites Zhang Zhideng and others, and first published in 1408. It was later reprinted with annotations and commentaries. Many subsequent Chinese encyclopedias were produced during the Ming and Qing dynasties. The earliest Chinese-Western encyclopedia "The Improvement of the Mind", was compiled by Cheng Yi (1231–1217), Shao Yong (1012–1077) and Cheng Yi's son Shao Kang (1161-1226), Cheng's son Shao Wen (1184-1260) and the famous Ming dynasty philosopher Wang Shouren. It was widely read during the Song dynasty. During the early Qing dynasty period, Xian Nanguang, Wang Qi and Wang Yinzhi (王胤之) published several encyclopedias, especially encyclopedias dealing with Confucian studies such as: Xuarao Kaiyao (学瑜珱開耶), Luoyong Zaoju (羅庸詣注), Sanlun Ganyuan (三論間船), Quotations from Zhu Xi (朱熹傳), Yongjiushi (永久私逸), Xiancaohang (獣才亢) and Yinfu (信府). Enthusiastic scholars in various fields, including medicine, astronomy, mathematics and geography, produced works in different formats. The 20th century saw the emergence of the first Chinese-English, English-Chinese and Chinese-Chinese encyclopedias which were widely published and distributed overseas and to the Chinese diaspora.

Since 2007, a massive effort has been made to create a Chinese National Encyclopedia. The new encyclopedia was initially called simply the "National Encyclopedia" (全国词典) and was published in four volumes (5420 pages) in May 2008, based on an editorial team of 10,000 people, funded by the Chinese National Government. This was followed by the publication of additional volumes; and finally the English-language version, "The National Encyclopedia of China",  was published in ten volumes in December 2010; this edition was edited by Qian Yingzhen and based on the full text of "Zhonghua Ditu" (中華辭典), the Chinese name of the encyclopedia.

== Classical Chinese encyclopedias ==
